ğŸ“š Book 14 ğŸ“š

I don't know what I was expecting when I started this book, but it wasn't  what it turned out to be. Not that it was a bad thing. I thoroughly enjoyed the story!! I don't think that I knew it was written from the dogs point of view, but I really loved how Garth Stein approached how a dog "thinks" as opposed to other authors. Enzo was a wonderful dog to get to know! The story was heartbreaking and uplifting at the same time. 

Now I can finally watch the movie!

ğŸ“šRead That

The Art of Racing in the Rain

Wonderful read! Really enjoyed this one as a emotional and thoughtful read. This is also my to entry for my wonderful friends @pupsplantsandplotlines giveaway /challenge for #pupsplantsandplotlines as I was able to get my pup to sit still for this one!

Enzo is a dog. But he knows he is different then other dogs because he has always felt more human then most. He knows that when his soul passes on from this life, in his next he will become a man. With his race car driver owner Denny, Enzo recalls his life learning about racing, life and what it means to be human.

Really emotional read for this one! Moments to make you laugh (everything from a dogs perspective is actually quite funny) and cry (anything sad with a dog is just about as sad as it gets..). I loved that this one felt so real! Real challenges, real characters and as my dog was looking at me, I felt like he would probably sound EXACTLY like this if he was narrating his own story.

The story feels deep yet somehow Enzo keep things simple. Itâ€™s all very black and white, right and wrong for a dog and I loved reading the story that way. You also learn a LOT about racing reading this so something else I quite enjoyed!

Worth the read for something different, emotional and wonderful all at once!

â €
Synopsis:
â €
â€œEnzo knows he is different from other dogs: a philosopher with a nearly human soul (and an obsession with opposable thumbs), he has educated himself by watching television extensively, and by listening very closely to the words of his master, Denny Swift, an up-and-coming race car driver.
â €
Through Denny, Enzo has gained tremendous insight into the human condition, and he sees that life, like racing, isn't simply about going fast. Using the techniques needed on the race track, one can successfully navigate all of life's ordeals.
â €
On the eve of his death, Enzo takes stock of his life, recalling all that he and his family have been through: the sacrifices Denny has made to succeed professionally; the unexpected loss of Eve, Denny's wife; the three-year battle over their daughter, ZoÃ«, whose maternal grandparents pulled every string to gain custody. In the end, despite what he sees as his own limitations, Enzo comes through heroically to preserve the Swift family, holding in his heart the dream that Denny will become a racing champion with ZoÃ« at his side. Having learned what it takes to be a compassionate and successful person, the wise canine can barely wait until his next lifetime, when he is sure he will return as a man.â€ â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ğŸ’«
â €

"There is no dishonor in losing the race. There is only dishonor in not racing because you are afraid to lose."

The Art of Racing in the Rain by Garth Stein
-
The blurb: â€œThe captivating and moving story of an extraordinary family, how they almost fell apart and how they were brought back together by the wisest and most loyal member - Enzo the dog.â€
-
My rating: â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸.5/5
-
Told from a dogâ€™s point of view, The Art of Racing in the Rain is a story about Denny, his love of car racing and how he is trying to keep his family together through some very tumultuous times.

I absolutely ADORED this book! It made me smile, it made me sad, at points it hurt my heart. Enzo is such a lovable character and makes me look at pets in a completely different way. What if they CAN understand us humans?? Not only is the book written from a dogâ€™s perspective, but also of an outsider looking upon situations, able to observe without being able to verbally react. It makes me think; if we were able to look at a scenario unfolding from a purely observational point of view, would we react differently? Would we say different things? Be more mindful of how the other person feels? Have more empathy?
-
